record.comment: The damage that the bullets cause. May be overriden in editor.

This defines the type of damage the bullets or weapon delivers. 0 - explosion (grenades, rpgs, etc). 1 - bullet shot (pistoles, rifles). 2 - shotgun/spread shot. Type 2 delivers more physical punch and uses cone for finding damage points. May inflict increased damage in practice.
This defines the accuracy of the gun's bullets. More is worse. May be overriden in editor.
This defines the accuracy of the weapon while running. The lower the number, the higher the accuracy
Sets the number of loops between shots on automatic weapons to X divided by 2. Set to 1 for the muzzle flash light to remain ON.
The range of the weapon's bullets. The default value is 1000 units.

record.recName: Rounds to fire per one shot
record.comment: This defines the number of rounds to fire in a single shot. For example, one mouse click may result 3 shots in a row. This only works on automatic weapons.
The number of bullets that should be shot in one firing. For example, one shot of shotgun may contain 11 bullets.
This defines the number of rounds per clip.
This defines the weapons as being its own ammo. Used for grenades.
This defines the flak model to use when the weapon is fired (see flakspec command list for further details regarding flak).
This defines what particle decal is used when the weapon is fired. The particle moves with the projectile.
This defines the speed at which the particle animation is played.
This enables weapons using the same ammo type to share ammo between them. Sharing is done by providing the same ammo *.fpe file for all the guns sharing that ammo.
If set to true, the player will be able to reload the weapon if it is full in order to receive one extra round.
If true then performs uses reload start, reload loop, and reload end animations.
If set to false then scoped weapons won't zoom out when reloading

If set to true, the player will not be able to reload when the weapon is full. NOTE: If Chambered Round = true, they will still be able to reload with full ammo to obtain 1 extra round. They will not be able to reload if they already have the additional round.
If set to true, the weapon can only be reloaded if it is empty.
This defines whether collected ammo is added directly into the clip or not if the weapon is empty.
This defines whether the gun will automatically reload when empty or not. Weapons auto reloads by default.
The number of shots fired before the chance of jamming becomes active.
The time in milliseconds from the last time the gun was fired that is needed to completely clear the current jam. Firing the weapon before the cool down duration has expired will reset the timer.
The chance of the gun jamming each time it is fired once over heated. The "Overheat after" setting must also be used. Reloading automatically resets gun jam. Value 0 is never, value 100 is always.
This sets the gun up to use either ironsights or the scope HUD when in zoom mode. To use ironsights, Ironsight Magnification (SIMPLEZOOM) must be set to 1
Used for ironsights when Use ironsights (ZOOMMODE) is set. Defines the amount that the player should zoom in when pressing right click.
This defines the accuracy of the weapon when in simple zoom, or ironsights. The lower the number, the higher the accuracy
This defines how much the camera moves around when in zoomed mode. Setting to zero means no movement.
This defines the full-screen HUD image to be used when in full scope zoom
The modifier for the player's walk speed while zoomed. Higher values mean the player will move slower.
The modifier for the player's looking speed while zoomed. Higher values mean the player will look around slower.
The amount of recoil on the vertical (or Y) axis (randomly selects up or down).
The amount of recoil on the horizontal (or X) axis (randomly selects left or right).
The percentage of the recoil that should be compensated for on the Y axis.
The percentage of the recoil that should be compensated for on the X axis.
The amount of recoil on the vertical (or Y) axis (randomly selects up or down).
The amount of recoil on the horizontal (or X) axis (randomly selects left or right).
The percentage of the recoil that should be compensated for on the Y axis.
The percentage of the recoil that should be compensated for on the X axis.
This defines the amount of damage the melee attack does. There are some recommendations about values from 100 to 120 for a powerful strike
This defines what key code activates the melee attack. For example, X is 45.
This defines the range at which the melee attack can cause damage in units. Setting this value between 50 and 60 is recommended.

This defines the key code (or key codes) needed to activate the alternative firing mode. A second key code can be declared to allow key-combos (such as “ALT +F”) to perform the switch. If the second key code is not declared, the first key code is used to switch between the firing modes. If nothing is declared, the default switch key is the number of the gun selected.
This defines whether the weapon's alternative fire mode is a flak type.
This defines whether the weapon's alternative fire is a bullet (ray cast) type.
If set to true, this disables the ability for the player to shoot while running.
If set to true, the player will not be able to fire the weapon when under water.
This defines the gun as a non-lethal equipment, rather than a weapon. Use this command when creating tools or other items that do no harm.
If the gun is set as an equipment and this is set to true, the player will be frozen/disabled for 100 ms when the equipment is activated.
If set to true, the weapon acts as a gravity gun. Right mouse click picks up and drops objects, left mouse click throws a held object.
If gravity gun is set: This defines the physics weight the gravity gun will handle. Objects heavier than this value will not be picked up.
If set to true, the weapon acts as a magnet gun. Left mouse click drags objects towards the player.
If magnet gun is set: This defines the physics weight the magnet gun will handle. Objects heavier than this value will not be attracted to the player. .
This defines whether the bullet hide system is used or not. Requires bullet's limbs to be named correctly (i.e. “BULLET1”).

record.recName: Hidden bullet's back to 100% at frame
record.comment: If hide system is used: defines the animation frame at which the bullets will all be scaled back to 100%.
If hide system is used: defines the amount of ammo spent before the bullet hide system operates.
This defines the number of bullet limbs that the weapon has.

record.recName: Disable animation speed change in move
record.comment: If set to true, this disables the animation speed change applied to the move animation while walking/running/crouching.
This defines the texture to apply to the gun model. Leave blank to use the model's default texture
Defines the file path to the effect file to be applied to the weapon
This defines the transparency of the gun, but how the value corresponds to the actual transparency varies depending on a number of factors such as the shader used..
This defines what brass or used shell model will be projected from the gun in random directions when fired. 1 for pistol 2 for rifle 3 for shotgun
This defines the standard smoke decal that is used when the weapon is fired. If no smoke decal is defined, the default is set as 1. 1 is for grey smoke, 2 is for blue.
This defines the smoke decal that is used when the weapon is fired and overrides the smoke setting.
This defines the speed at which the smoke is animated. The default value is 25

This defines how the character holds the weapon, what impact decal is applied and is limited to six variations: 0 is for grenades, 1 if for pistols 2 is for machine guns, 3 is for rifles, 4 is for miniguns, 5 is for RPGs
This positions the gun towards or away from the camera/player. Negative values position the gun closer to the camera
This positions the gun left or right from the default position in relation to the camera/player. Negative values position the gun left
This positions the gun up or down from the default position in relation to the camera/player. Negative values position the gun down.
This defines the angle of the gun around the x-axis.
This defines the angle of the gun around the y-axis.
This defines the angle of the gun around the z-axis.
The speed at which the gun should lag behind the camera movement. Higher values mean the gun moves slower and further.
The maximum amount the gun can lag behind on the X axis.
The maximum amount the gun can lag behind on the Y axis.
This defines how much the gun model lags behind the player while moving in ironsights zoom.
The maximum amount the gun can lag behind on the X axis while moving in ironsights zoom.
The maximum amount the gun can lag behind on the Y axis while moving in ironsights zoom.
An X offset to use while running (holding shift and moving). NOTE: The weapon is smoothly transitioned to this position using SIMPLEZOOMSPEED.
An Y offset to use while running (holding shift and moving). NOTE: The weapon is smoothly transitioned to this position using SIMPLEZOOMSPEED.
High values mean the weapon does not move backwards as much when the player zooms in. Negative values mean it moves forward. A value of zero means it does not move
The speed at which the weapon is smoothed to the X/Y values. Higher values mean it goes slower/smoother.
An X offset to use when in simple zoom. The weapon is smoothly transitioned to this position using Zoom-in Speed.
An Y offset to use when in simple zoom. The weapon is smoothly transitioned to this position using Zoom-in Speed.
If set to true, the weapon will not place a bullet hole on walls. Useful for melee weapons
The sets the melee action not to leave bullet holes.

This defines the scorch mark made by the weapon's bullets on the segments. The number refers to the image below, but the scorch mark can be further customised by replacing the bulletholes.dds image within the bulletholes folder. By default, 0-2 are pistol/rifle, 3-4 are shotgun, 5-7 are explosions, 8-11 are blood, 12-15 are specific by material.
Type of pre-defined muzzleflash, where: 1 is 6-star, 2 is 8-star, 3 is 5-star, 4 is fire cloud, 5 is green fire cloud, 6 is light shaffle, 7 is big fire cloud
This defines the size of the muzzle flash decal
This defines the decal that will show up in front of the weapon when the weapon is used by a character (i.e. it will NOT show up when the player fires the weapon)
This aligns the muzzle flash along the horizontal axis. Positive values move the muzzle flash right.
This aligns the muzzle flash along the vertical axis. Positive values move the muzzle flash up.
This aligns the muzzle flash along the weapons axis (in/out of the screen). Positive values move the muzzle flash away from the player.
This sets the amount of red emitted from the muzzle flash spot light. If all three muzzle colour components (red, green and blue) are set to zero, the red component will be set to 255
This sets the amount of green emitted from the muzzle flash spot light. If all three muzzle colour components (red, green and blue) are set to zero, the green component will be set to 255
This sets the amount of blue emitted from the muzzle flash spot light. If all three muzzle colour components (red, green and blue) are set to zero, the blue component will be set to 0
If set to false the muzzleflash will not use the zoom alignment coordinates.
This aligns the muzzle flash along the horizontal axis when in zoom. Positive values move the muzzle flash right.
This aligns the muzzle flash along the vertical axis when in zoom. Positive values move the muzzle flash up.
This aligns the muzzle flash along the weapons axis (in/out of the screen) when in zoom. Positive values move the muzzle flash away from the player.
This defines the speed of the animations (keyframe ratio).
This defines the animation frames for when the weapon is idle.
This defines the animation frames for when the player is walking.
This defines the animation frames for when the player is running. If no run animation frames are provided, the gun will use the move animation frames.
This defines the animation frames for when the player selects the weapon.
This defines the animation frames for when the weapon is put away or hidden.
This defines the animation frames from alternative fire mode to normal fire mode
This defines the animation frames from normal fire mode to alternative fire mode
This defines the animation frames for when the weapon changes firemode between normal and alternative ammo
This defines the animation frames for when the weapon jams while being fired
This defines the animation frames for when the weapon jam is being cleared.
This defines the animation frames for when the unarmed hand is pressing a button.
This defines the animation frames for when the unarmed hand (or the player) dies.
This defines the animation frames for when the unarmed hand is pushing.
This defines the animation frames for when the unarmed hand is taking something.
This defines the animation frames for when the player is using the weapon (when it is defined as an equipment)
This defines the animation frames for when the weapon is firing.
This defines the animation frames for when the weapon is reloading.
This defines the animation frames when the gun is automatically firing
This defines the animation frames for when the gun is being cocked. If no cock animation frames are provided, the gun will use the reload animation frames.

This defines the animation frames for when the player is firing the weapon. Up to three start fire animations can be defined for normal and alternative fire modes. The engine randomly picks which fire animation to use.

This defines the animation frames for when the player is firing the weapon. Up to three start fire animations can be defined for normal and alternative fire modes. The engine randomly picks which fire animation to use.

This defines the animation frames for when the player is firing the weapon. Up to three start fire animations can be defined for normal and alternative fire modes. The engine randomly picks which fire animation to use.
This defines the animation frames for when the weapon has finished firing.
This defines the animation frames for when the weapon has finished firing.
This defines the animation frames for when the weapon has finished firing.
n: This defines the animation frames for when the player is reloading the weapon.
This defines the animation frames for the weapon's reloading loop.
This defines the animation frames for when the weapon has finished reloading.
This defines the weapon to use the empty animations when out of bullets.
This defines the weapons to use both empty and shotgun type animations.
This defines the animation frames for when the gun is idle and it has no ammo. If no empty idle animation frames are provided, the gun will use the normal idle animation frames

This defines the animation frames for when the player is walking with the gun and the gun has no ammo. If no empty move animation frames are provided, the gun will use the normal move animation frames
This defines the animation frames for when the player is running with the gun and it has no ammo. If no empty run animation frames are provided, the gun will use the empty move animation frames
This defines the animation frames for when the gun is being selected and it has no ammo.

This defines the animation frames for when the gun is being hidden or put away and it has no ammo. If no empty put away animation frames are provided, the gun will use the normal put away animation frames
This defines the animation frames for when the gun is being cocked and it has no ammo. If no empty cock animation frames are provided, the gun will use the normal cock animation frames.
This defines the animation frames for when the gun is being reloaded and it has no ammo.

This defines the start animation frames for when the gun is being reloaded and it has no ammo. If no empty start reload animation frames are provided, the gun will use the normal start reload animation frames.
This defines the animation frames for the reload loop when the gun has no ammo. If no empty reload loop animation frames are provided, the gun will use the normal reload loop animation frames.

This defines the end animation frames for when the gun is being reloaded and it has no ammo. If no empty end reload animation frames are provided, the gun will use the normal end reload animation frames.
If set to true the weapon will use the zoom animation set when in ironsights.
This defines the animation frames to be played when the gun is moving into ironsights mode
This defines the animation frames to be played when the gun is moving out of ironsights mode
This defines the animation frames for when the gun is idle and it is in zoom mode.
This defines the animation frames for when the player is walking with the gun and it is in zoom mode
This defines the animation frames for when the gun is being automatically fired and it is in zoom mode
This defines the start animation frames for when the gun is being fired and it is in zoom mode
This defines the end animation frames for when the gun is being fired and it is in zoom mode.
This defines the animation frames for when the player is performing the block action whilst holding the gun.
This defines the start animation frames for when the player is performing the melee action whilst holding the gun
This defines the end animation frames for when the player is performing the melee action whilst holding the gun
This defines the start animation frames for when the player is performing the melee action whilst holding the gun and the gun has no ammo
This defines the end animation frames for when the player is performing the melee action whilst holding the gun and the gun has no ammo
This defines how quickly the fire sound is looped. Lower values make the sound loop quicker.
The percentage of sound the player‟s weapon will make in the AI system. A value of 0 means it will make no sound, while 100 would be normal.
This defines the sound to be used by the gun. The sounds are triggered by using the Sound Frame # command.
This defines the sound to be used by the gun. The sounds are triggered by using the Sound Frame # command.
This defines the sound to be used by the gun. The sounds are triggered by using the Sound Frame # command.
This defines the sound to be used by the gun. The sounds are triggered by using the Sound Frame # command.
This defines the sound to be used by the gun. The sounds are triggered by using the Sound Frame # command.
This defines the sound to be used by the gun. The sounds are triggered by using the Sound Frame # command.
This defines the sound to be used by the gun. The sounds are triggered by using the Sound Frame # command.
This defines the sound to be used by the gun. The sounds are triggered by using the Sound Frame # command.
This defines the sound to be used by the gun. The sounds are triggered by using the Sound Frame # command.
This defines the sound to be used by the gun. The sounds are triggered by using the Sound Frame # command.
This defines the sound to be used by the gun. The sounds are triggered by using the Sound Frame # command.
This defines the sound to be used by the gun. The sounds are triggered by using the Sound Frame # command.
This defines the sound to be used by the gun. The sounds are triggered by using the Sound Frame # command.
This defines the sound to be used by the gun. The sounds are triggered by using the Sound Frame # command.
Number of used sounds (in main fire mode).
This defines the animation frame at which to play the specified sound file. The sound files are defined using the Fire Sound # command.
This defines the animation frame at which to play the specified sound file. The sound files are defined using the Fire Sound # command.
This defines the animation frame at which to play the specified sound file. The sound files are defined using the Fire Sound # command.
This defines the animation frame at which to play the specified sound file. The sound files are defined using the Fire Sound # command.
This defines the animation frame at which to play the specified sound file. The sound files are defined using the Fire Sound # command.
This defines the animation frame at which to play the specified sound file. The sound files are defined using the Fire Sound # command.
This defines the animation frame at which to play the specified sound file. The sound files are defined using the Fire Sound # command.
This defines the animation frame at which to play the specified sound file. The sound files are defined using the Fire Sound # command.
This defines the animation frame at which to play the specified sound file. The sound files are defined using the Fire Sound # command.
This defines the animation frame at which to play the specified sound file. The sound files are defined using the Fire Sound # command.
This defines the animation frame at which to play the specified sound file. The sound files are defined using the Fire Sound # command.
This defines the animation frame at which to play the specified sound file. The sound files are defined using the Fire Sound # command.
This defines the animation frame at which to play the specified sound file. The sound files are defined using the Fire Sound # command.
This defines the animation frame at which to play the specified sound file. The sound files are defined using the Fire Sound # command.
This defines the animation frame at which to play the specified sound file. The sound files are defined using the Fire Sound # command.
